messageBody:
Hiya, having just started a new job, as way of getting my head around some
of the code, I was asked to write some unit tests, and after writing a heap
of them, I noticed that the test itself was always the same, which just
different settings.

I was also told that they'd like our testing guy to be able to make up new
tests on the fly, so I wrote a new test which loaded an XML file, which
took care of defining what I wanted to test for, and get back. The test
code looks like this:

public void testUnmarshelledMessage() {

try {
File path = new File("/home/mark/testmessages");
File[] files = path.listFiles();

for (int i = 0; i < files.length; i++) {
File file = files[i];
if ( file.getName().startsWith("test") &&
file.getName().endsWith("xml")) {
Reader reader = new FileReader( file.getAbsoluteFile()
);
TestMessage testMessage = (TestMessage) readObject(
reader );
MessageStatus result = sender.send(
testMessage.getMessage() );
assertEquals( file.getName() + "(" +
testMessage.getName() + ")",
testMessage.getResult(), result.getStatusCode() );
}
}
} catch ( Exception e ) {
fail( e.getMessage() );
}

}

So the test finds all files starting with test and ending with xml in the
specified directory, calls readObject() to unmarshall the XML file into my
TestMessage object, and does the test, and checks the result. This is all
working nicely, untill I wrote a test that failed.

Because this test is just that, one test, once it failed, none of the other
XML files got processed. So I've been trying to think of a way around it,
a way to run my test method against each XML file as its own test.

I had thought of writing a custom TestSuite which took the path, found the
files, and added a custom TestCase with the filename ( instead of method
name ), and moving the actual test code above into the custom TestCase,
however I'm not quite sure the best way to implement this.

Any ideas?

Mark
